subject_prompt_600:
Jeanne Moreau's favorite films include The Crying Game, Taxi Driver, The Exterminating Angel, The Silence of the Lambs, My Name Is Joe, My Fair Lady and Chinatown.

Moreau was also a fan of the British film The Man Who Knew Too Much.

Dates of birth, marriages and deaths:

1874 (age 37) - Died from a heart attack at her home on November 4th, 1918.

1916 (age 36) - Married to a man named Raymond, who died in June 1942.

1947 (age 43) - Passed away on February 21st, 1947 due to an unknown cause.

1950 (age 57) - Died December 26th, 1950.

1958 (age 44) - Died July 17th, 1958.

1961 (age 48) - Died February 18th, 1961.

1963 (age 38) - Passed away on March 10th, 1963 from complications resulting from a stroke. She had been suffering from severe rheumatoid arthritis for years and rarely left her bedroom.

1964 (age 38) - Passed away on September 8th, 1964.

1967 (age 48) - Passed away on February 29th, 1967 from complications of a stroke.
coupled_prompt_600:
Denis d'Inès (born in 1774) lived most of his life in Brussels and wrote some of the best-known French poetry in the 19th century. He was an eccentric figure, having a taste for eccentricity and not holding back when he went to war in 1805. After being wounded in the battle of Waterloo, he spent many weeks in a state of total paralysis which ended with the death of his wife. This was the start of a long bout with depression that left him crippled for life. When he finally recovered in 1816, it was in part through the intervention of the poet John Donne. Although the two were friends, it is unlikely they ever met.
It is probably fair to say that this is just a snapshot of Denis d'Inès. Some of the ideas in it are not entirely accurate, the dates are a bit off and perhaps others could be mentioned, but hopefully you get the gist. I would like to acknowledge the help of the folks at the National Archives of Belgium. The following information will only work if you have access. If you do not, then feel free to send an email to me and I will get in touch with you directly.
The information on this page has been drawn from the records and documents of the National Archives of Belgium, Belgium, on file since August, 1995. It was provided to me by the Archives as a PDF on July 2nd of 2009. The information contained on this page has not been verified or updated and does not represent the current position of the Archives, the Belgian government or the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. For further information regarding Belgian records, please contact The National Archives of Belgium, Brussels, Belgium, Tel.: +32(0)2 542 64 66
